channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Clinics for World’s Vulnerable Brace for Trump’s Anti-Abortion Cuts
item.media:description: A woman suffering from complications caused by an unsafe abortion at a hospital in Zongo, the Democratic Republic of Congo, in 2015. The so-called Mexico City policy prohibits organizations abroad from using American aid to discuss abortion as a method of family planning.
item.description: Health workers say President Trump’s ban on abortion counseling will hurt even those health services that do not involve abortions.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY, NORIMITSU ONISHI and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: His Predecessor Gone, Gambia’s New President Finally Comes Home
item.description: The president, Adama Barrow, had fled to neighboring Senegal more than a week earlier after Yahya Jammeh, his defeated predecessor, refused to cede power.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Mexico’s President Cancels Meeting With Trump Over Wall
item.description: The move by the Mexican leader, Enrique Peña Nieto, brings to a head the simmering tensions that have been building for months between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: In a Corner, President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico Punches Back
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico this week. His cautious approach to President Trump had caused an outcry in Mexico.
item.description: The cancellation of his trip to the United States ended months of diplomacy for a leader caught between his people and an unpredictable, and at times hostile, American president.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Wheels: China’s Answer to Tesla Is Hopeful Entrant to Global Car Market
item.media:description: Lu Qun, chairman of Qiantu Motor, in Beijing in December.
item.media:credit: Patrick Wack for The New York Times
item.description: Electric vehicles offer a new chance to Chinese car-making efforts that have floundered in the past. But lavish state aid could be as much bane as boon.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHUMAN

item.title: South Korea Can Keep Buddha Statue Stolen From Japan, Court Says
item.media:description: Sekko Tanaka, a Buddhist monk on the Japanese island of Tsushima, in 2013, holding a photograph of a Buddha statue that was stolen the year before.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: The ruling found that the 20-inch bronze statue had been taken from Korea centuries ago by Japanese pirates. Tokyo called the decision “regrettable.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Chinese New Year: Inside the World’s Largest Trek
item.media:description: Passengers at the Beijing West Railway Station. Hundreds of millions of Chinese are traveling to their hometowns for the Lunar New Year, the country’s most important holiday.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: Tens of millions are traveling from industrial regions to their hometowns to celebrate. The holiday rush is not a tranquil experience, but it has become more orderly.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and ADAM WU

item.title: Professor Who Wrote of Korean ‘Comfort Women’ Wins Defamation Case
item.media:description: Park Yu-ha, the author of “Comfort Women of the Empire,” in Seoul, South Korea, in 2015.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Park Yu-ha, a professor in Seoul, was found not guilty of defaming women forced by the Japanese to work in brothels during World War II.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Ordered to Seek Approval on ‘Brexit,’ Theresa May Does So. Tersely.
item.description: At 132 words — one of the shorter bills in British history — the bill was seen as an effort to prevent amendments that could slow its passage.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: The Interpreter: British Alignment With Trump Threatens European Order
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain arriving at Philadelphia International Airport on Thursday for her two-day visit to the United States. She will be the first world leader to meet with President Trump.
item.description: Britain has much to lose whichever way it turns, but it seems more concerned with its departure from the European Union than other global events.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Bana al-Abed Writes Trump: ‘Please Save the Children and People of Syria’
item.description: The girl, 7, and her mother, Fatemah, posted an open letter to President Trump on Bana’s Twitter account, sharing the message with the hundreds of thousands of users who follow the account.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Beirut Journal: On Lebanon’s Once-Sparkling Shores, a Garbage Dump Grows
item.media:description: A beach flooded with garbage on the outskirts of Beirut. The garbage problem has long been a symbol of a failure of Lebanese politics, one that activists say has its roots in the time shortly after the country’s civil war, which ended in 1990.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: A landfill that is attracting birds that endanger aviation is a symbol of dysfunction to many in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: What in the World: Polish City to Give Tom Hanks the Car That Put It on the Auto Map
item.media:description: A gathering of Fiat 126p enthusiasts in Krakow, Poland. “The Maluch was the beginning of an automotive revolution in Poland,” said Jacek Krywult, the mayor of Bielsko-Biala, Poland, where the car was made.
item.description: The Maluch, built in Bielsko-Biala from the early 1970s to 2000, has developed a following that apparently includes at least one prominent fan.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: Stephen P. Cohen, Secret Broker of Mideast Peace Talks, Dies at 71
item.media:description: Stephen P. Cohen in 1984. One Israeli politician described him as “the lone guerrilla warrior of peace.”
item.description: Mr. Cohen arranged the first direct and informal talks between the Israeli government and Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Canada Beckons International Students With a Path to Citizenship
item.media:description: Eun Young, a student from South Korea, at the College of the North Atlantic in St. John’s, Newfoundland, in November.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Universities are welcoming students from abroad as part of a government strategy to offset the country’s aging population and slowing birthrate.
item.dc:creator: CRAIG S. SMITH

item.title: White House Sows Confusion About Plan for a 20% Import Tax
item.media:description: President Trump in his office aboard Air Force One on Thursday.
item.description: Sean Spicer, the White House press secretary, appeared to endorse the plan as a way to pay for a wall on the Mexican border, but then backtracked.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR, BINYAMIN APPELBAUM and ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: ‘This Feels Like Being Born Again:’ Gambians Hope for Change and Long for Home
item.media:description: Gambians on Saturday in Banjul, the capital, hearing about the imminent departure of Yahya Jammeh, who had refused to step down as president after losing an election.
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: As the new president takes power, we asked readers from Gambia about their hopes and fears for their homeland, and, for those abroad, whether they might return.
item.dc:creator: LILLIE DREMEAUX
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: ‘Give Us Our Children Back’: Hunger Strikers in Sri Lanka Demand Answers
item.description: In pushing officials to investigate the disappearance of thousands after a civil war ended in 2009, hunger strikers won a meeting with the country’s defense minister.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS and GEETA ANAND

item.title: Greece’s Top Court Rejects Extradition of Turkish Officers
item.description: The Supreme Court ruled that they would face “the curtailment of their fundamental human rights” if they were sent back to Turkey.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Eike Batista, Once Brazil’s Richest Man, Is Sought in Corruption Inquiry
item.media:description: Eike Batista, second from left, during a court hearing in Rio de Janeiro in 2014.
item.description: The police are seeking the arrest of Mr. Batista, an oil and mining magnate, in connection with bribes paid to the former governor of Rio de Janeiro.
item.dc:creator: DOM PHILLIPS and SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Q. and A.: How Trump’s Revival of an Abortion Ban Will Affect Women in Kenya
item.media:description: A group gathered for counseling on family planning options in western Kenya.
item.description: A family planning fellow discusses what President Trump’s ban on aid to groups who offer abortion counseling could mean for women in western Kenya.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: Zimbabwe Stands Still as President Vacations Off the Grid
item.media:description: President Robert Mugabe, 92, Zimbabwe’s ruler of 37 years, has received up to $1.2 million for his trips, a former minister said.
item.description: Cabinet meetings are not held and government decisions are put off during President Robert Mugabe’s annual extended trips to Asia, which are funded by the nation.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MOYO and NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: For Justin Trudeau, Canada’s Leader, Revival of Keystone XL Upsets a Balancing Act
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s welcome of the Keystone XL reversal in Washington has alienated many environmentalists in Canada, and has also strained his relations with some indigenous communities.
item.media:credit: Todd Korol/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: President Trump’s move to proceed with the pipeline project leaves the Canadian prime minister facing anger from both energy advocates and environmentalists.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: W.H.O. Warns of Worrisome Bird Flu in China
item.media:description: Culling birds in Hong Kong in 2014 after the H7N9 virus was discovered in poultry imported from China.
item.description: A strain of avian flu has hospitalized more than 225 people in China since September, and may have jumped from person to person at least twice.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: A Roar, Then Cold Darkness: Avalanche Survivors Recall 3-Day Ordeal
item.media:description: Giorgia Galassi, left, and Vincenzo Forti, two of the 11 survivors of the avalanche that hit the Hotel Rigopiano last week.
item.description: Guests at the Hotel Rigopiano in central Italy recounted the three days of frigid darkness before rescue crews pulled them out.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Sent Home for Not Wearing Heels, She Ignited a British Rebellion
item.media:description: Nicola Thorp, holding a pair of flat shoes deemed inappropriate by her temp supervisor, went on a British morning television show Wednesday. She prompted lawmakers to take up her complaint about dress codes unfair to women.
item.description: A parliamentary inquiry prompted by a receptionist’s complaint has concluded that laws against discriminatory dress codes for women needed to be tougher.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: François Fillon, French Presidential Hopeful, Faces Inquiry Over Payments to Wife
item.media:description: François Fillon and his wife, Penelope, at a campaign rally in Paris, in November.
item.description: In a development that could upend the election, prosecutors opened an investigation after a newspaper reported that Mr. Fillon’s wife had been paid $535,000 for a no-show job.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: A Bloody Reminder for Somalia: Chaos Is Never Far Away
item.media:description: A wounded man at a hospital in Mogadishu, Somalia, after an attack at a hotel in the capital on Wednesday.
item.description: A New York Times reporter made his first trip to Mogadishu in years. He was impressed by the progress. Then the bombs went off.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Top Russian Cybercrimes Agent Arrested on Charges of Treason
item.description: An officer in the cyberintelligence unit of the Russian Federal Security Service and a private cybersecurity analyst were reportedly taken into custody.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: As Trump Orders Wall, Mexico’s President Considers Canceling U.S. Trip
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico before giving a foreign policy speech this week in Mexico City. He has so far resisted pressure to respond more forcefully to President Trump’s provocations.
item.description: Mexicans called President Trump’s push to build a wall “an offense to Mexico,” a “slap in the face” and a “monument to lies.”
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Pressure Builds for Modi to Overhaul Indian Campaign Finance
item.description: A New Delhi nonprofit reported that almost 70 percent of contributions to the nation’s political parties come from undisclosed sources.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: Russia Moves to Soften Domestic Violence Law
item.description: Defenders of the change to the law say it protects the rights of parents to discipline their children, but critics say it is a license for violent behavior.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Sinosphere: The Little-Known Role of Western Economists in Building a Post-Mao China
item.media:description: The Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping, left, with Premier Zhao Ziyang in an undated photo. Zhao oversaw the development of many of the market-oriented policies behind China’s economic transformation in the 1980s.
item.media:credit: Forrest Anderson/The LIFE Images Collection, via Getty Images
item.description: The reform period ushered in by Deng Xiaoping also drew on the wisdom of foreign advisers, according to the Oxford scholar Julian Gewirtz.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Kuwait Hangs 7 Convicts, Including a Prince
item.description: The executions of two Kuwaitis and five foreigners were the first in the country in over three years and reflected a wider return to the death penalty in the region.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: ‘The Greatest Forest Disaster in Our History’: Wildfires Tear Through Chile
item.media:description: The central Chilean region of Bío Bío on Monday.
item.description: For days, raging flames have devastated a wide swath of the South American country.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Jaipur Journal: A Political Jolt at a Literary Festival, but Courtesy Wins Out
item.media:description: Writers, journalists and publishers at the Penguin Random House India party on the sidelines of the recent Jaipur Literature Festival.
item.media:credit: Poras Chaudhary for The New York Times
item.description: The right-wing group that gave rise to Narendra Modi, India’s prime minister, was allowed a coveted place at the Jaipur Literature Festival.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: North Korean Defector Says Kim Jong-Un’s Control Is Crumbling
item.media:description: Thae Yong Ho, second from left, at a news conference in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday. He was North Korea’s No. 2 diplomat in London until he fled to the South last summer with his family.
item.description: Thae Yong-ho, the highest-ranking official in years to flee, said that the regime’s control was weakening as a result of corruption and popular discontent.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: For First Time in Years, Japan Boasts a Sumo Grand Champion
item.media:description: The sumo wrestler Kisenosato was hoisted aloft in celebration of his promotion to yokozuna, or grand champion, after a ceremony in Tokyo on Wednesday.
item.description: The wrestler Kisenosato has become the first Japanese athlete to receive the sport’s highest title, yokozuna, since 1998.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Skepticism and Support in South Korea as Ban Ki-moon Weighs Presidential Bid
item.media:description: Ban Ki-moon, the former United Nations secretary general, upon his arrival at the Seoul Railway Station in South Korea this month.
item.description: After a 10-year run as the secretary general of the United Nations, Mr. Ban returned home to residents imploring him to run and critics who say he couldn’t restore trust in government.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: A Times Photographer’s Inside Look at the War on ISIS in Mosul
item.media:description: The aftermath of a suicide car bombing in Andalus.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: Our photographer was embedded with an Iraqi special forces unit in Mosul, where Islamic State militants have been pushed west across the Tigris River. But 750,000 people remain in areas under the militants’ control.
item.dc:creator: IVOR PRICKETT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Editorial: Mr. Trump’s ‘Gag Rule’ Will Harm Global Health
item.media:description: Women in Rabai, Kenya, getting information about family planning and reproductive health services.
item.media:credit: Jonathan Torgovnik/The Hewlett Foundation, via Getty Images
item.description: The president has greatly expanded a policy restricting federal aid to health organizations abroad that talk to women about abortion.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: God Is Back – in France
item.media:description: François Fillon, a former prime minister who is running in the French presidential election in the spring as the nominee of the main center-right Republican Party.
item.description: Catholics are emerging as a political force in the French presidential campaign.
item.dc:creator: SYLVIE KAUFFMANN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Remove the Catholic Church From Auschwitz
item.media:description: The church at the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camp in Poland last year.
item.description: This pope has been a force for interfaith understanding. That’s needed now, to move a convent still operating where a million Jews were killed.
item.dc:creator: AVI WEISS
